entry.title: Important Information About Converting Renumbered G/L Accounts with an Active Parallel Line:
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

We've recently gotten some feedback regarding a specific point in the conversion process for renumbered G/L accounts and wanted to take a quick minute to spread the word as widely as possible.

When you're converting renumbered G/L accounts on a three-system landscape, that conversion process means a development system downtime (typically 2-4 hours). During this downtime, your business users can't access the SAP Fiori launchpad, so day-to-day business in the development system is blocked for that period of time.

So far, so good. But what if you have an active parallel line? 

In that case, the conversion process means a downtime for both development systems at the same time. It doesn't matter whether or not the accounts were branched (from the main line to the parallel line, or vice versa) or whether they exist in one line only: Converting renumbered G/L accounts in either  the main line or  the parallel line means a downtime for the development system across both lines.

Please keep this in mind when you're scheduling the conversion process for your renumbered G/L accounts!

As always, further information can be found on the SAP Help Portal.

And of course, if you have follow-up questions here, or want to know more about the renumbering process for your G/L accounts, feel free to ask in the comments--we can answer or make new posts to clarify additional issues that arise!

entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 1
entry.content:
Introduction:

Hello everyone, Myself Sriram Balaji, I am currently working as an SAP FICO Consultant. Last year, I got an opportunity to work in SAP Public Cloud Greenfield Implementation Project. During the “FIT to Standard” and “UAT” sessions, we have demonstrated the SAP standard Customer / Supplier Aging Analysis Report to the client but they are not satisfied with the standard aging report. They required a tailored Aging Analysis Report for Customer and Supplier, one that aligned perfectly with their unique operational requirements. This experience highlighted the importance of understanding client expectations beyond standard functionalities and fueled my journey into customizing SAP solutions in the Public Cloud.

In this blog, we are going to explore how we can develop Customized Customer (AR) Aging Analysis Report using the “Key User Extensibility” in the SAP Public Cloud.

 

Purpose of Preparing Customer Aging Analysis Report:

Customer Aging Analysis Report, is a basic financial report which provides the information of outstanding payment from the customer’s and how long they are due for the payment by categorizing into the Aging Buckets (0 – 30 Days, 31 – 60 Days, ……. Above 365 Days).

The aging report provides vital information to management to evaluate how effective the business is at converting sales to cash. The aging report is also used as a tool for estimating potential bad debts, which are then used to revise what is known as the allowance for doubtful accounts.

 

Key-User Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud:

Extensibility covers a broad spectrum of topics that enable customers and partners to adapt standard business software to their business needs.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud key user extensibility allows adapting standard functionalities to user requirements without the need for any external tools. Key User Extensibility is done in the customizing tenant of the development system through SAP Fiori apps designed to facilitate someone making small changes to apps, reports, and email and form templates without any coding experience.

Here's an overview of the things you can do using key user extensibility tools:

  • Change and adapt the UIs for SAP Fiori Apps
  • Create Custom Fields
  • Create your own custom templates or extend the standard forms and email templates
  • Create customer-specific CDS Views
  • Enhance the current business process by creating custom business logic
  • Create a new custom user interface
  • Create custom business objects

SAP S/4HANA embodies key user extensibility tools, which are completely web-based. They are targeted at key users who have a deep knowledge of the product itself, but not necessarily a very deep technical knowledge.

For more details about Extensibility in SAP S/4 HANA Public Cloud, please refer the link https://extensibilityexplorer.cfapps.eu10.hana.ondemand.com/ExtensibilityExplorer/#/ReadMore

To develop the Customized Customer Aging Analysis Report, we are going to use the below Key-User Extensibility Apps and other provided Apps by SAP in the Public Cloud:

  • Custom CDS View APP
  • Custom Analytical Queries APP
  • View Browser APP
  • Custom Catalog Extensions APP

My prior experience in developing Aging Analysis Reports in SAP ECC and S/4HANA GUI with my technical team allowed me to apply the same logic to Custom CDS Views and Custom Analytical Queries, even without knowing any deep technical knowledge.

Let me summarize the business requirement for Customer Aging Analysis before jumping into the technical steps involved for the development:

  • The report should display: Customer Account, Customer Name, Document Number, Line Item, Document Type, GL Account, Payment Terms (with descriptions), and other required fields.
  • The report should calculate and present: Overdue Days, Not Yet Due, Aging Buckets (0-30 days, 31-60 days, …... and Above 365 days), and Total Overdue Amount.
  • The report balances must be matched with the 'Manage Customer Line Items' App (Accounts Receivable Ledger).

 

In this Part - 1, We will explore how we can utilize the Custom CDS View APP for the AR Aging Analysis Report development.

 

Custom CDS View:

Custom CDS views can serve different purposes: They can be consumed in analytics or serve as external APIs to be consumed in external systems, for instance the SAP BTP. Especially Cube or Dimension views can be used in analytical scenarios and also you can create or modify a custom CDS view by,

  • Adding fields from multiple data sources.
  • Creating your own calculated fields.
  • Refining the properties of the selected fields.
  • Creating and maintaining parameters for the usage within your view.

We have combined the multiple data sources such as I_JournalEntryOperationalView, _I_GLAccountText, and _I_PaymentTermsText to create a Custom CDS View by using the Join Condition.

 

Step – 1: Open the APP – Custom CDS View

Click on “Create”.

 

Enter the “Label”, Choose the “Scenario” – “Analytical Cube” and Click on “Create” Button.

Note: By choosing the Scenario as “Analytical Cube”, We can use this CDS View to create an Analytical Queries for the Customer Aging Analysis report.

 

Step – 2: Choose the Primary Data Source 

Click on “Add” Button

Choose the “Primary Data Source”

Note: Data Source is an object containing the key figures and characteristics from the database and it provides a multidimensional analytical view of business data.

 

Select the respective “I_JournalEntryOperationalView” Data Source from the list.

 

This I_JournalEntryOperationalView CDS view provides access to all details of a journal entry item (database table ACDOCA) joined to the details of the corresponding operational accounting document item (database table BSEG) and to the details of the corresponding journal entry header (database table BKPF) including the most important business entity, such as G/L account, Cost Center or Profit Center.

So, this I_JournalEntryOperationalView is similar to the ACDOCA Table which contains the values of all the relevant fields related to the Accounting Document.

 

Step – 3: Choose the Associated Data Sources

Click on “Associated Data Sources”

Note: Associated Data Sources will help us to combine the two different data sources into one CDS View by using a join condition set between two or more equal characteristics present in the Primary Data Source – A and Associated Date Sources – B that contains the same data type.

For Example:

The primary data source "I_JournalEntryOperationalView" does not include the "Payment Terms Description" field. Therefore, we must join it with the associated data source "I_PaymentTermsText" using a join condition to retrieve this field.

Select the “Join Condition” Icon.

 

Click on “Add”

 

Choose the common field that available in the both Primary & Associated Data Source to join.

 

Select the Value Type as “Field”

Click on F4 in the Value Field.

 

Find the corresponding "Payment Terms" mapping field in the Primary Data Source to link it with the field in the Associated Data Source.

 

Select the Value Type as “Session Variable”

Choose the Value as “System Language” and Click on “Close” button.

 

Step – 4: Choose the Elements (Fields) to be added in the CDS View

In the Elements Section, Click on “Add” button and Choose “Elements”.

In the Elements selection pop up screen,

Choose the “Elements (Fields)” from “I_JournalEntryOperationalView” you want to display in the CDS view and then Click on “OK”.

Total 142 Elements (Fields) have been selected for the CDS view.

 

Step – 5: Create User Defined Parameters

User-Defined Parameters:

Parameters usually require data input when your custom CDS view is executed. This data can then be used like a variable e.g. in filters, calculated fields or even in a join condition to another view. You can then refine them or just create your own parameters if you need them.

The Customer Aging Analysis Report will operate based on "Open Items at Key Date," mirroring the functionality found in reports like "Manage Customer Line Item" or "FBL5N."

The "Open Items at Key Date" logic ensures that when the report is run for a specific date (which can be in the past, present, or future), it will only display items that meet following criteria mentioned below:

  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were not yet cleared as of the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared after the specified key date will be included in the report.
  • The open items (Invoices, Payments, & Advances) were cleared before the specified key date will be excluded from the report.

This "Key Date" will serve as a crucial input on the report's selection screen, driving the logic for determining which open items are included in the Customer Aging Report.

In the Parameters Section, Click on “Add” button,

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Data Type: “DATS” – Date (YYYYMMDD Format) Data type of the parameter.
  • Default Type and Value: “Manual” - Enter a manual parameter value in accordance with the data type syntax, e.g. for the data type DATS enter a manual value in the format YYYYMMDD.

Now the “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter is created. 

 

Step – 6: Add User Defined Parameters in the Elements (Fields)

In the Elements Section, Click on “Add” Button and Choose the “Parameters”.

Select the created “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter and Click on “OK” button.

Now the “Open Items at Key Date” Parameter has been added in the Elements.

 

Step – 7: Using “Filter” Applying the Logic for the Customer Aging Analysis Report

You can filter the information shown in your custom CDS view by setting up a condition, just like using the WHERE clause in SQL. This condition provides the view exactly what data to show.

Think of it like this:

The CDS view (I_JournalEntryOperationalView) which we are using that shows all the Accounting Document transactions in line item wise.

  • If you want to display only Customer related Accounting Transactions, you'd set a condition like "Account Type is equal to “D".
  • Or, if you only want to see Normal Transactions (Invoices, Payments) & Special GL Transactions (Advances), your condition would be "Special GL Code equal to “BLANK”, & “A”.

Once you set this condition (using either a simple editor or a form-based one), your CDS view will automatically filter its results, showing only the open items that match what you asked for. It's a way to fine-tune the data you see without having to look through everything.

We can use the form-based version to define simple filter conditions. In case you want to define more complex conditions, we can use expression-based version. Here, we have used expression-based version.

As per business requirement, to ensure the Customer Aging Analysis Report balances match with the "Manage Customer Line Items" balances, we've set up specific conditions for these fields: Account Type, Special GL Code, Posting Date, and Clearing Date in the Filter section using expression-based version.

 

Step – 8: Create Calculation Elements (Fields) – Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days

In the Elements section, click on “Add” button and Choose “Calculation” to create Overdue Days & Payment Terms Days fields for the report.

  1. Overdue Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as “Function” and Choose “Function Type – Date and Time”
  • Choose the respective “Function - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN” and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on “Create”.

Note: The function DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN calculates the difference between two specified dates, date1 and date2, in days. The actual parameters must have the predefined data type DATS and should contain a valid date in the format YYYYMMDD.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Overdue Days is Open Items Key Date (which was created as parameter for report execution) MINUS Net Due Date. 

 

  1. Payment Terms Days

Enter the following information:

  • Name: Technical Name
  • Label: Name to be displayed in the output of the parameter
  • Choose as “Function” and Choose “Function Type – Date and Time”
  • Choose the respective “Function - DATS_DAYS_BETWEEN” and apply the below mentioned formula.
  • Then click on “Create”.

The Formula we have applied to calculate the Payment Terms Days is Net Due Date MINUS Baseline Date.

Created Calculation Elements (Fields) for the report.

In the Element Properties Section, Maintain the Aggregation method as “No Operation” for the created Payment Term Days & Overdue Days Fields to convert the field into calculated measure for creating the Aging Buckets in the Custom Analytical Query APP.

 

Step – 9: Preview and Publish the created CDS view

In the Log section, check any error need to rectified before preview the CDS view.

Click on “Preview Data” button to display the values are coming as per the logic or not.

 

Created CDS View no of line items are matching with the Manage Customer Line Items.

Calculated Fields (Overdue Days, Payment Terms Days) are displaying with values in the CDS View according formula we have applied in the calculation function.

Once Check is successful, Go to “Next Steps” section.

Click on “Publish” button to publish the Created CDS View for Creating Analytical Queries.

In Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.

entry.title: Developing a Customized AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud - Part 2
entry.content:
In this Part - 2, we'll dive into using the Custom Analytical Queries APP with our newly created Custom CDS View to build an AR Aging Analysis Report.

 

Please refer Part - 1 to Understand the Custom CDS View created for the AR Aging Analysis Report:

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/developing-a-customized-ar-aging-analysis-report-in-sap-s-4hana-public/qaq-p/14163727

 

Custom Analytical Queries APP:

The Custom Analytical Queries APP is like a smart tool that helps you create your own reports and analyze your business data, even if you're not a tech expert.

Imagine you're trying to build your Customer Aging Analysis Report. Instead of writing complex computer code, this app takes all the raw numbers and information (like invoices, payments, and dates) and turns them into an easy-to-understand table or grid. It hides all the difficult technical stuff, so you just focus on what you want to see.

Here's how it helps you design your report:

Pick and choose your data: The app provides all the available fields from the business transactions. For your aging report, you'd select fields like Customer Name, Invoice Number, Posting Date, Due Date, Amount Due, and Clearing Date.

Filter what you see: You can set filters to narrow down your report. For example, you might filter to see only particular customers, or invoices past their due date by more than 365 days.

Create custom calculations: You can add restricted measures (like "Total Overdue Amount for 30-60 Days").

See results instantly: You can preview your report as you build it, so you know exactly what the final output will look like.

 

Step – 1: Open the APP – Custom Analytical Queries

Click on “Create” button.

 

Enter the “Query Name”, Choose the “Data Source” – which we have created as a CDS View.

Click on “OK”.

 

Step – 2: Name the Analytical Query

In the General Tab,

Enter the “Label” for the AR Aging Analysis Analytical Query and Click on Next Tab “Field Selection”.

 

Step – 3: Field Selection for the Analytical Query

In the Field Selection Tab,

Choose the required fields from the Available Fields by selecting the “Check box” to display in the AR Aging Report.

 

Step – 4: Arrange the Selected Fields in the Analytical Query

In the Display Tab,

Select relevant Field and Choose the “Axis” - Row / Column. Once selected the Axis, the field will be automatically moved to Row / Column Tab same as Company Code, Customer etc.

Note: Arrange the fields according to the business format and also Amounts / Numerical / Calculation related fields are arranged under the Measure Structure of Column Axis.

 

Step – 5: Choose the Input Parameter Fields for the Report

For the AR Aging Analysis Report, users need to provide input parameters such as Open Items at Key Date, Customer, Company Code, GL Account, and Posting Date to generate the report based on their selections.

In the Filter Tab,

Choose the respective Field and then Select the radio button “Uset Input Values”.

Select the “Default Value” if required.

Note: Our AR Aging Analysis report runs based on the Open Items at Key Date, showing all items not cleared by that date. If you need to pre-fill any input fields, you can use the Default Value functionality in the filter section.

For Example: Below are the selected Input Parameters for our report and the “Open Items at Key Date” and “Company Code” will be defaulted at the time of report execution based on the settings in Analytical Queries.

Step – 6: Create Calculated Measure Fields (Aging Buckets) for the Report

Creating Aging Buckets is the most challenging aspect of developing the AR Aging Analysis Report. This is primarily due to the complexity of applying the necessary formulas. To build custom aging buckets, you'll need a foundational understanding of IF & Else conditions, similar to those used in Excel, to grasp the CASE WHEN Expression formulas utilized in SAP Analytical Queries.

 

  1. Not Yet Due (Aging Bucket - 1)

In the Display Tab,

Click on “Add” button and Choose “Add Calculated Measure” to create the Aging Bucket.

Then Enter the “Label” and Click on “OK”.

We've now added a "Not Yet Due" field to the query. This field displays the Amount in Company Code Currency for any customer open items with Overdue Days less than or equal to zero.

The above logic has been applied in the analytical query using the CASE WHEN formula.

In the Expression Section,

Choose the “Edit” button to apply the formula.

Select the “Function” button then Choose the “Case Expression” and Click on “OK” button.

The formula applied in this “Not Yet Due” field is, if the Overdue days field is less than or equal to “0” then “Amount in Company Code Currency” should be displayed in the report or Else the value should be displayed as “0”. You can Choose the Measure fields by click on measures button or else you can type relevant measure field in the Expression editor. Once formula applied the Click on “OK”.

 

  1. 1 to 30 Days (Aging Bucket – 2)

Apply the same steps involved in Not Yet Due field, only the formula will be changed for this 1 to 30 Days Aging Bucket.

For the "1 to 30 Days" field, we've applied a specific formula:

If a Customer Open item's Overdue Days are greater than or equal to "1" AND less than or equal to "30," the Amount in Company Code Currency will be displayed. Otherwise, the value will show as "0." This formula uses an AND condition to accurately identify customer open items that are between 1 and 30 days overdue.

After applying the formula, simply click "OK."

 You can apply this formula and change the conditions according to the Aging Buckets (31 to 60 Days, 61 to 90 Days…etc).

The Sum of all the Aging Buckets from “1 to 30 Days till Above 365 Days” will be the “Total Overdue Amount”.

Once the respective fields created in the Custom Analytical Queries APP.

Click on “Save Draft” the changes will be saved. Then click on “Preview” option to validate the report values.

 

Step – 7: Preview and Validate the Created Custom Analytical Query

In the Input Parameters, The Open Items at Key Date and Company Code will automatically default the value according to the settings in Custom Analytical Queries APP and also it can be changeable at the time of report executing.

Once maintained the Input Parameters, Click on “GO”.

You can validate the output of the report in the Preview. So, the issues will be identified and resolved before publishing the Custom Analytical Query for the APP creation.

 

Step – 8: Publish the Created Custom Analytical Query for AR Aging Analysis Report

Click on “Publish” to publish the created Custom Analytical Query for the AR Aging Analysis Report APP creation.

 

View Browser APP:

For SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition key users, the View Browser app is essential for finding CDS views. This includes both SAP-released and custom CDS views.

The app provides a comprehensive list of available CDS views. You can see details like Category, View Types, Dimensions and Measures, Annotations, supported capabilities, and modelling patterns. It also offers robust search options. You can search by descriptions, application components, or even the tables used to build the CDS views.

Beyond searching, you can use the View Browser to analyze a CDS view's data fields. The application displays all CDS views and their underlying artifacts in tables. By default, views are organized by name, but you can also filter column values using a dropdown.

While you can't change SAP-created CDS views in the View Browser, the Custom Analytical Query app allows you to create, save, modify, and publish your own CDS views to catalogs.

 

Step – 1: Create the Application for Created Custom Analytical Query

Open the “View Browser” APP.

Search the Created AR Aging Analysis Analytical Query in the Search Bar and then Click on the respective Analytical Query to Create the Application.

You can check the Fields, and CDS View involved in this Analytical Query.

Click on “Create Application”.

Choose the “Language”

Enter the “Title” and “Subtitle” for the Report and this will be the Application Name.

Click on “OK”.

Finally, the Application is created for the developed AR Aging Analysis Report.

 

Custom Catalog Extensions APP:

This app lets you assign your apps to specific business catalogs. After creating a new app, you must link it to the necessary catalogs. To use your new app, you'll need to assign a business role that includes that Catalog.

 

Step – 1: Open the APP – Custom Catalog Extensions

Select the Created Application to assign it to the respective Business Catalog.

 

Step – 2: Assign Business Catalog to the Application

Click on “ADD”.

 

Choose the respective “Business Catalog” and then Click on “OK”.

Select the Business Catalog and then Click on “Publish” button.

Confirm by choosing the “OK” to publish.

Finally, the Created Application is assigned with the Business Catalog and published for the business usage.

 

Step – 3: Display the APP - AR Aging Analysis – Report

Once the APP is assigned with the Business Catalog, you can search the created APP in the search bar to display it for the reporting purpose.

 

References / Acknowledgements:

I'd like to extend my sincere thanks to the various SAP documentation, community blogs, and helpful tutorials that guided me through the intricacies of Key User Extensibility in SAP S/4HANA Cloud.

I highly recommend them for anyone looking to dive deeper into SAP S/4HANA Cloud extensibility:

  1. https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-members/customer-aging-and-supplier-aging-reports-at-the-line-item-level-using/ba-p/13563839
  2. https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/creating-custom-cds-views-and-analytical-query-a-step-by-step-guide/ba-p/13508914
  3. https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0f69f8fb28ac4bf48d2b57b9637e81fa/e30de6eae4d24d70b65996ac8ff88848.html?locale=en-US&version=2502.500

 

Conclusion:

Developing a customized Customer AR Aging Analysis Report in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, as demonstrated, truly highlights the power and flexibility of "Key User Extensibility." While standard solutions offer a solid foundation, the ability to adapt and build tailored reports is crucial for meeting unique business requirements and ensuring user satisfaction.

By leveraging apps like Custom CDS Views, Custom Analytical Queries, the View Browser, and Custom Catalog Extensions, key users can effectively design and deploy robust financial reports without extensive technical coding. This empowers organizations to gain deeper insights into their financial data, streamline processes, and make more informed decisions regarding accounts receivable management.

This project was a testament to how SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition enables businesses to go beyond standard functionalities, proving that with the right tools and a clear understanding of business needs, powerful custom solutions are well within reach.

Thank You!

entry.title: Structured address data elements in ISO 20022 messages
entry.content:
Introduction

ISO 20022 includes data elements to capture additional information regarding the parties (entities and persons) involved in the transaction. Each party’s name and address is defined in a granular structure that distinguishes ‘Name’ and the various components of address – ‘Building Number’, ‘Street’, ‘Town’, ‘Country’ (code), etc. (see table below). In MT, a name and address are represented by four lines each of 35 characters, either in an unstructured format or with a structure that distinguishes only name, country code, city and other details.

 

Unstructured address version will end on Nov 2025

Due to the coexistence period of both ISO 20022 and MT formats, in cross-border payments, current practices will be accommodated. Until November 2025, ECP usage guidelines allows both, structured and unstructured address, to be used in a mutually exclusive way, i.e., either unstructured address in the ‘Address Line’ element or structured address in the dedicated tags can be used

Given that as of November 2025 payments must be initiated using structured ISO 20022 party addresses, this may represent a challenge for the corporates that maintain address data elements of their customers, suppliers and counterparties in an unstructured database

 

Hybrid address version

The hybrid address version is a mix of structured and unstructured address details. It allows the combination of structured ISO 20022 address elements and up to two lines of 70 characters of unstructured “Address Line” . Elements available in a structured format must be mapped into the respective structured address elements. The structured elements “Country” <Ctry> and “Town Name” <TwnNm> are mandatory. Content of structured elements cannot be repeated in the <AdrLine> elements.

 

Structured addresses in SAP delivered mappings

 

SAP delivers format mapping templates which implement only the structured address version for formats based on ISO20022’s 2019 version .

PAIN.001.001.09 and PAIN.008.001.08

All sub-tags of <PstlAdr> are defined* for later use in custom copies as shown on the right side. (*see Activate/deactivate a node on SAP Help portal)

SAP Notes:

  • 2784858 for SAP S/4HANA Private ERP
  • 2253571 for SAP ERP

Please check with your house bank for their specific requirements with regards to Structure/Hybrid address handling.

entry.title: Cash and Liquidity Management : Data Migration
entry.content:
Hello and welcome to the blog post for Data Migration for Cash and Liquidity Management. In this post, we’ll cover essential guidance and highlight key considerations to keep in mind before migrating your Cash Management data.

1. The decision.

Before you decide to take on migration, there are two questions that need to be answered.

  1. Do you need Cash and Liquidity Management ?
  2. If the answer to above question is yes, then you need Cash Position or Liquidity analysis or both ?

In this blog, we are assuming that you are migrating to OP 2021 or to a higher OP version. From OP 2021, there is a new way of dealing with cash management data, where cash position flows and liquidity analysis flows are handled separately.

The second question is important from an operational point of view, as Liquidity analysis takes a bit of time since the flow builder plus executes with 9 steps of chain tracing. Cash Position is relatively quicker in execution time, and if you don‘t require liquidity analysis, then you need not spend memory resources for liquidity analysis.

 2. Before Migration. 

            a. If you are using S/4 Hana, and an earlier OP version, you would be using Flow Builder 1.0 program for Cash Management. You need to ensure that the entries in FCLM_BSEG_DELTA and FCLM_MM_DELTA are processed as they come. If there are huge number of records in the above table, then you can take one out of the following three approaches.

  • You can process all the entries stuck in the delta table, by executing the flow builder 1.0 program for running type Delta Run Based on Queue Table, and with Max Steps of Chain Clearing = 4. This will take some time, if you have more than a hundred thousand entries. The four steps of chain clearing, also known as liquidity analysis, will take more time for execution.
  • You can process all the entries stuck in the delta table, by executing the flow builder 1.0 program for running type Delta Run Based on Queue Table, and with Max Steps of Chain Clearing = 0 (Cash Position). This will take less time, due to 0 chain steps, and it will keep the cash management updated enough for the migration to go through.
  • You can delete all the entries from the delta table by writing a Z* program, and then deactivate source applications temporarily. After migration, you can again activate the source applications and execute the flow builder plus manually in mass run mode, so that cash management is reinstated again. This option is only useful if your business can handle deactivation of cash flow reports till the data is migrated.

           b. If you are in ECC system, then kindly go through the below notes. The below notes should give you a brief idea about the new tables/ transactions that are being used.

 0002270400 - S4TWL - Cash Management – General

 0002726878 - S4TWL - Obsolete Transaction Codes and Programs in Cash and Liquidity Management

You can read more about flow builder plus in the KBA 0003520602 - Flow Builder Plus: General Consulting Queries. It’s important to understand, in S/4 Hana, that all cash management data is populated into table FQM_FLOW, also known as One Exposure.

Complete the cash management configuration in the new system, by referring Note 0003111810. If you are only interested in Cash Position, then maintain as such in the source application accounting. Also ensure that the workflow is enabled for automatic execution of cash position into FQM_FLOW. If you are interested in Liquidity Analysis, or both, then setup the jobs and do the configuration as mentioned in the above note.

3. After migration/ Cutover activity.

           a. If you are migrating from an earlier version of S/4 Hana to a newer version, FCLM_FI_STAGING gets all the data dump from all the cash relevant documents present in BSEG table. The configuration that you have defined will populate the data into FQM_FLOW. However, you may face memory issues, if you have data in millions, all of which are getting executed in one go by flow builder.

  • If you have more than couple of million entries in the staging table, the best course would be to just stop the event linkage DELTA_RUN_REC, and also the background jobs for liquidity analysis. You can pick a time when the system is not overwhelmed with various jobs, and can schedule the delta run for cash position and liquidity analysis, manually. Again, this option is to be only used if business can handle without cash flow reports for a while.
  • You can also execute delta run for cash position manually every couple of hours. The execution of cash position does not take much time, and it might help business with the relevant reports. However, liquidity analysis will take time and you should execute the same when the system is bit free.

           b. If you are migrating from ECC system, documents will start coming to FCLM_FI_STAGING, once the data starts migrating to BSEG table. You can follow the above points here as well. The only difference, here, would be that data will come gradually to FCLM_FI_STAGING and not at a time.

You can reinstate the cash position’s event linkage DELTA_RUN_REC and the liquidity analysis‘ event based background job, once the entries in the staging table are in control. Its worthwhile to note that you may face higher CPU and DB load after the migration, for which its important to be prepared. You can do the mock migration in UAT phase, in order to have an idea about system performance and the number of entries you would actually be migrating during the cutover.

4. What happens if there are huge amount of data left in FCLM_BSEG_DELTA ?

This is discussed in KBA 0003566758, which you can refer. You may not be able to work with normal FI/MM transactions, as the system will try to transfer all the delta records to staging table. In this case, you need to write a Z* program to delete the delta entries and execute mass runs in flow builder plus for all company codes relevant to cash management.

(Note: If cash management is activated, FI/MM documents are created and then populated in the staging table. If there are records in the delta table, the system will move those to staging table as well).

5. In OP 2021,  after switching from Flow Builder 1.0 to Flow Builder plus, old flows are not categorized separately as Liquidity/Cash position flows.

After migration from flow builder 1.0 to flow builder plus, the flows from flow builder 1.0 (with owner GCC) are termed as 'Shared flows' meaning that they can be used both as Cash Position and Liquidity Analysis flows. If you have opted for 'Cash Position and Liquidity Analysis', then the flows that will get created from the flow builder plus will have owners GCC and POS. The flows created by the old flow builder program with owner GCC can be left as it is, as those flows represent both cash position and liquidity analysis.

6. How to migrate flows from other source application areas, such as TRM, PAYRQ, etc.

For source applications other than FI and MM, you need to use FQM_INITIALIZE transaction. After the data is migrated for sales orders, payment requests, treasury deals, etc. and then execute FQM_INITIALZE for the company codes. FQM_INITIALIZE is relevant for below:

  • CML(Customer and Mortgage Loans) Consumer and Mortgage Loans in One Exposure from Operations | SAP Help Portal
  • PAYRQ (Payment Request)
  • FICA(Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable) Contract Accounts Receivable and Payable (FI-CA) in One Exposure | SAP Help Portal
  • REFX (Lease and Contract Management)
  • SDCM(Sales and Distribution)Sales and Distribution in One Exposure from Operations | SAP Help Portal
  • TRM (Treasury and Risk Management)

7. Old data coming to FQM_FLOW

Data that is present in BSEG table, if cash relevant, will come to FQM_FLOW. This has been discussed in KBA 0003604654. If you do not want flows prior to a certain date in FQM_FLOW, you can implement your own logic in BADI 'BADI_FQM_FLOW_ADJUST_CORE'.

In OP 2023, you can configure a start date in 'Define Start Date for One Exposure' configuration, after which ACTUAL flows prior to that date will not flow to FQM_FLOW. The configuration can be found in the below path:
SPRO-->SAP Reference IMG--> SAP Customizing Implementation Guide--> Financial Supply Chain Management--> Cash and Liquidity Management--> Cash Management--> Data Setup--> Define Start Date for One Exposure

8. Customizations in the upgraded system.

The customization logic previously implemented in the CALL_HADI method of the loading classes in the legacy S/4HANA system for Flow Builder 1.0 needs to be re-written and re-implemented in the new system within the BADI ‘BADI_FQM_FLOW_ADJUST_CORE’.

9. Data Transfer between ECC and S/4 Hana and between other systems.

You can refer to Integration with Remote Systems to understand the configurations and proxy settings to be done for transfer of data from ECC to S/4 Hana.

Go through the Note 0003345963 , to transfer One Exposure Cash Flow from your SAP S/4HANA On-Prem system to other S/4HANA system.

Go through the Note 0003345981 , to transfer One Exposure Cash Flow from your SAP S/4HANA Cloud system to other S/4HANA system.

10. If Cash management is not required.

You can deactivate cash management, by deactivating the source applications, and then delete the data present in the staging tables and FQM_FLOW table by writing a Z* custom program. Cash Management can be late re-activated by activating the source applications and then execute the flow builder plus in mass run mode, to update Cash Management data in One Exposure.

In conclusion, cash and liquidity management is a very adaptable product and can be deactivated and re-activated anytime. The flows can be rebuilt anytime, once the systems are stable. This would not have any implications, and there is no fear of data loss or duplication. I hope this blog helps you achieve a smooth migration and prepares you from any issues that may happen.

entry.title: Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud
entry.content:
Organizational Structure - SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud

In order to understand the organogram of any organization, it is essential to learn the functions of every org unit. Just like in a family, some people play the roles of guardians, supervisors and some are only dependents on elder, likewise SAP org units are. 
Every organization utilizes its resources to earn profits so from where can we extract the profitability reports? It means there is a unit made responsible to collect information, analyse and report it in every manner that is "CO-PA". (Controlling- Profitability Segment). So, Operating Concern is like a super power who sits on the top of the org structure and have all the information. In SAP Public Cloud one operating concern is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other.   It is assigned to controlling area, where all variable and fixed costs of the company is stored. Just like there cannot remain two swords in one sheath, similarly two controlling areas cannot be created. In SAP Public Cloud one controlling area is predefined with name of A000 therefore CO Consultant do not need to create any other. 

The world of Finance begin when companies start trading, hence just like we have multiple universes, multiple company codes are assigned to controlling areas. Company code is the smallest org structure in FI that stores all financial documents line items. It becomes a base for MM and SD structure, an independent family member upon which other gets dependent. Company codes nomenclature can be alpha-numeric. FI Consultant will begin the org structure creation activity in SAP Public Cloud. Lets take one scenario as an example. lets say a group of companies will be made as a company and its subsidiaries will be configured as separate company codes. 

Plant is the area which is responsible to record every production activity. What is happening inside a plant, cannot be known to that person who is sitting on the head of the family chair on the dining table. (CO-PA). Therefore, MM Consultant configures the alphanumeric plants to the company codes and with this relation, correct information passes to controlling area and reports of profit gets extracted. Profit is made of Revenue-Costs, so costs are available with controlling area, but what about revenue? 

So we have another stream, another module i,e SD who is solely responsible to dispatch and record sales. Then like a river, it flows into the sea of Finance and gets connected to CO-PA. 

MM and SD are two extreme opposite sides, SD is a plus and MM is minus. (Inflows and outflows) MM has its own purchasing org, that can either be centralized or decentralized as per company's policies. 
Similarly, SD has its own sales org,  SD consultant can assign one on multiple company codes or create a decentralized structure. 

In connection to controlling area. CO consultant designs a hierarchy of cost centers and profit centers to record their activities. Purchases can be found in multiple cost centers, and via report it can be plan to control it. Whereas, sales can be assigned profitability segments to know their contributions in profit figures. 

Under plant, multiple storage locations for inventory can be configured and assigned and under the same plant, sales area is made. Sales area is the combination of sales org, divisions and distribution channel. The longest activity in org structure is of SD module.  

The material is either procured externally or produced in-house, it moves from plant to warehouse, then stamped in sales office, it dispatches from shipping points to final consumer and consumer happily transfers the receipt in company's bank account. That's how production is materialized into finance. 

Please note no consultant can begin configuration without completing the organisational structure. 

It can be edited and recreated later on. but it will lock your workspace for sometime. After doing changes, confirm the units and deploy it onto your configuration server. 

Reports are formulated with the help of transactions, if a purchase order is made in MM, check the org units, (plant, purchasing org and storage location)  will be filled, so automatically it will be assigned to its respective company code and would reach CO-PA. SD will also follow the same in its preliminary financial documents. Hence, create a strong structure to uphold the data in correct formats and form. 

Till now, we have CO-FI-MM and SD in the picture and that's how organisational structure is framed in SAP S/4 Hana Public Cloud. The role of CO is predefined, in Grey cannot be changed in any circumstances.

entry.title: Switching Your Tax Procedure or External Tax Provider (United States Sales and Use Tax)
entry.content:
To state the obvious: Getting your taxes right is an important part of your business, and it’s not an area where you’d typically seek out additional complexities.

This is the shortest possible version of why it’s difficult to change your sales and use tax procedure in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. Your tax procedure is something you set up in your initial scoping, and it is in most cases the deepest asleep of all of your sleeping dogs. Almost all the time, you just want to leave it alone.

Almost. There are times when you need to make a change. Perhaps your business structure has changed sufficiently that you want to move from the internal tax calculation procedure to the external and join up with a tax partner. Or maybe you need to switch tax partners.

In these cases, with live systems, you need to think carefully, plan for disruption, think again, and plan some more. And then probably do that one more time. Then if you’re going ahead, consult our KBA entitled Information on the Internal Tax Calculation Procedure (TAXUSJ) to the External Tax Calculation Procedure (0TXUSX) for more detailed information on the procedure, risks, and potential downtimes associated with such a switch.

entry.title: Accounting Principles and SAP S/4HANA FI
entry.content:
It’s common to hear colleagues from other S4Hana modules express frustration with the complexity and impact of FI/CO on their processes. However, this perception often stems from a fundamental misunderstanding: the organizational structure of SAP S/4HANA Finance is not merely technical; it is the practical embodiment of the accounting principles that govern the financial governance of any organization.

Every object, from Company Code to Segment, is meticulously designed to ensure that financial records adhere to the pillars of accounting—promoting integrity, transparency, and, crucially, supporting strategic decision-making.

This article explores the intrinsic relationship between accounting principles and organizational objects in SAP S/4HANA FI, demystifying why their influence is so broad and vital to a company’s financial health. Get ready for an analysis that goes beyond technical configuration, diving into the accounting logic behind each system structure.

I’ve broken the concepts into levels to make them easier to understand.

 

Level 1: The Legal Entity and Going Concern in SAP S/4HANA

The starting point of any robust accounting system lies in properly defining the entity and in the premise of its uninterrupted operation. In SAP S/4HANA, these concepts are solidly embedded in its foundational organizational objects.

Entity Principle: The Company Code as the Legal Unit

The Entity Principle is one of the pillars of accounting, establishing that a company’s assets are distinct from those of its owners or shareholders. Accounting is therefore maintained for the business entity as an economically and legally separate unit.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Company Code is the most direct and crucial representation of this principle.

The Company Code is the smallest organizational unit for which a complete and self-contained set of accounts can be created, enabling the generation of external financial statements such as Balance Sheets and Income Statements, as required by law. Configuring a Company Code in SAP is, in fact, defining the legal and asset boundaries that the Entity Principle demands.

All financial transactions—whether purchases, sales, or payments—are recorded within a specific Company Code, ensuring segregation and clarity of each legal entity’s finances.

Going Concern Principle: The Long-Term Assumption in FI-AA

The Going Concern Principle assumes that the entity will continue operating indefinitely, with no intent of liquidation or significant downsizing. This is fundamental for classifying assets and liabilities (current vs. non-current) and, notably, for depreciating assets over their useful lives.

In SAP S/4HANA, the long-term existence of the Company Code, together with specific modules like Fixed Assets (FI-AA), reflects this principle directly.

FI-AA, configured per Company Code, manages asset depreciation across multiple years—a process that only makes sense under the assumption of continued operations. The system is inherently designed to handle the full lifecycle of assets and liabilities, which is a direct and systemic application of the Going Concern Principle.

 

Level 2: Measurement and Recording of Activities – The Basis of Accounting in S/4HANA

Once the entity is established, the next step is ensuring all financial activities are measured and recorded consistently and accurately. SAP S/4HANA provides robust tools aligned with essential accounting principles.

Monetary Unit Principle: Currency and Chart of Accounts

The Monetary Unit Principle requires all transactions and economic events to be expressed in a single currency. This enables aggregation, comparison, and consistent analysis of financial data.

In SAP S/4HANA, this principle is realized through the Company Code Currency and the Chart of Accounts.

Each Company Code is configured with a local currency (e.g., BRL, USD), in which all legal reports are generated. Regardless of the original transaction currency, amounts are converted and recorded in this common denominator. The Chart of Accounts, assigned to the Company Code, provides the structured hierarchy for recording economic events in an organized and standardized manner, allocating monetary values to categories such as Assets, Liabilities, Revenue, and Expenses.

Accrual and Matching Principles: The Universal Journal as the Core of Recording

The Accrual and Matching Principles are critical for accurate income determination.

  • Accrual Principle: Revenues and expenses must be recognized in the period in which they are generated, regardless of cash flow.

  • Matching Principle: Revenues must be matched with the expenses that contributed to generating them, preventing distortions in the Income Statement.

SAP S/4HANA fundamentally operates on an accrual basis. Fiscal Year Variants structure periods (usually monthly) and control postings, ensuring that an August sales invoice is recorded in August, even if payment occurs in September.

The Universal Journal (ACDOCA table) is the “single source of truth.” Every posting of revenue or expense is registered with both posting and document dates, ensuring proper period recognition. By unifying FI and CO data, the Universal Journal enables direct matching of revenues with their related costs—all in one place.

Native integration across SD (Sales & Distribution), MM (Materials Management), and FI automates matching. For instance, a goods issue in SD automatically triggers inventory reduction in MM and simultaneously records both Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) and revenue in FI. Likewise, FI-AA automatically posts depreciation monthly, while Cost Centers in CO record operating expenses that can be matched against generated results.

 

Level 3: Managerial Analysis and Reporting – Beyond Statutory Accounting

Beyond legal requirements, managers need granular insight into business performance. SAP S/4HANA applies accounting principles at an internal level to provide valuable managerial insights.

Segment Reporting (IFRS 8): The Segment Object

IFRS 8 (CPC 22 in Brazil) requires publicly traded companies to disclose information about their operating segments, enabling investors to analyze the business as management does.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Segment object is specifically designed for this. Derived at posting (often from Profit Centers), it enables real-time balance sheets and income statements per segment via the Universal Journal, providing unprecedented transparency into performance across business lines or geographies.

Internal Matching Principle: Profit Center and Cost Center

For managerial performance evaluation, revenues must be matched with the costs incurred to generate them.

  • Profit Center: Represents a unit accountable for its own P&L, capturing revenues and expenses. It applies the matching principle internally, enabling profitability analysis of products, branches, or divisions.

  • Cost Center: Represents where costs are incurred (e.g., HR, IT), without directly generating revenue. Costs are controlled here and can later be allocated to Profit Centers for full profitability analysis.

Together, Profit and Cost Centers close the cycle of internal matching.

 Prudence (Conservatism) Principle: Credit Control Area

The Prudence Principle dictates that, when in doubt, record the least favorable outcome—lower assets/revenues and higher liabilities/expenses. In practice, this means caution and recognition of probable losses.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Credit Control Area embodies this principle. By setting credit limits and monitoring exposures, it helps manage default risk. Functionality like provisions for doubtful accounts (bad debt allowances) within FI applies prudence directly, recognizing probable expenses before losses materialize.

 

Level 4: Information Quality and Systemic Governance in S/4HANA

Building an accounting structure is just step one. The next, equally critical, is ensuring that the information flowing through it is reliable, consistent, and accurate. SAP S/4HANA achieves this via its integrated architecture and intrinsic controls—systemic embodiments of governance and data quality principles.

Consistency Principle: Operational Chart of Accounts and Posting Models

The Consistency Principle requires that companies apply the same accounting practices across periods, allowing comparability over time. Changes are allowed only if preferable and properly disclosed.

In SAP S/4HANA, the Operational Chart of Accounts—once defined—becomes the backbone of all postings. Using a single chart across a group ensures uniform treatment of similar transactions across entities. Posting Models and Screen Variants enforce standardized postings for recurring transactions, reinforcing consistency and reducing manual errors.

Integrity, Completeness, and Synchronization of Data: Universal Journal and Native Integration

Data governance principles—Integrity, Completeness, Synchronization—are fundamental to information reliability.

  • Integrity ensures accuracy and trustworthiness.

  • Completeness ensures all required data is captured.

  • Synchronization ensures consistency across accounting, managerial, and logistics views.

The Universal Journal achieves this by merging FI, CO, FI-AA, CO-PA, and ML into a single line-item repository. This eliminates complex reconciliations.

Native integration ensures that when goods movement is posted in MM, the corresponding FI entry is simultaneously generated. No batch transfers that can fail; if one part fails, the transaction is reversed entirely, ensuring integrity.

The Universal Journal structure, containing all relevant fields (company, account, cost center, profit center, segment, etc.) in one table, ensures completeness. Its “single source of truth” architecture means all views—statutory and managerial—are instantly updated, eliminating reconciliations that plagued earlier SAP versions.

 

Conclusion: SAP S/4HANA as an Enabler of Accounting Governance

Understanding the deep connection between accounting principles and SAP S/4HANA FI architecture is crucial for every consultant. Far from being just a transactional system, S/4HANA is a platform that incorporates and automates accounting principles, ensuring not only legal compliance but also real-time financial insights for strategic decision-making.

By mastering this synergy, consultants can go beyond technical configuration and act as true business partners—optimizing processes, safeguarding data integrity, and maximizing the value SAP S/4HANA delivers to financial governance.

The evolution of ERP into S/4HANA represents a qualitative leap in how companies manage their finances—transforming accounting principles into operational and strategic reality.

entry.title: Plant Maintenance Integration with FICO,MM,PP, QM,HCM,EHS and other modules
entry.content:
Plant maintenance integrates with many of the modules and below are the some of the modules that plant maintenance integrates with: 

FICO(Finance and controlling) :- 

Below are the integration points of plant maintenance with FICO.
Company Code: - A plant will always be assigned to the company code. 
Cost center: - Cost Center is an organizational unit within a controlling area that is used to collect and record costs incurred from business activities.
Investment order: -  investment order needs cost budgeting for an order will be done.
Allocation Structure: -  In the allocation structure the cost elements will be taken from the CO in which these cost elements will gets reflected is any maintenance order have consumption of materials, Labour cost, 3rd party material procurement etc... which will flow the costs to the FI. 
Asset master creation: - When an equipment is being created then the asset will be created with a configuration.
Settlement Of an Order: - The settlement of an order is actually being done for an order because at the cost needs to be settled.
Settlement Profile: - The settlement profile will be assigned to the order type.
Activity Type: - In activity type the price or the cost for labour per hour will be determined by FICO consultant and we need to maintain the activity type in the work center.

PP(Production Planning) :- 
Work Center: - In work center the capacity will be determined by the production planning team. Here the capacity refers to the availability of people and resources for maintenance work.
Equipment Master Data: - In equipment master data there is a field work center in the Location in which we need to give the production planning work center and whereas in the organization. 
Spare Part Preparation: - For example the spare part cannot be procured externally then the spare part will be produced by the production order and the settlement rule of order will be done to the maintenance order.
Refurbishment of Material:- Refurbishment of material will be done if any material in production needs to be repaired as soon as possible then we will just refurbish the material and replace the material within the machine as it was there before the breakdown.

MM(Material Management):-
Components:- The components that are required for maintenance of machine will be taken from the inventory.
Service Entry Sheet:- To procure the service from external that is the maintenance has to be done for a machine and there is no team that is present in the plant(internal team) then we will just raise purchase requestion from the maintenance order and after it the material management people will procure the service through ML81N."
Split valuation:- Split valuation for a material has to be configured so that we can perform the refurbishment order.
Details of plant:- The details of plant related namely Purchase Organization, Vendor, Supplier, Outline agreement number etc..
Serial Number Profile:- A serial number profile must be configured for the material to enable the creation of equipment for that material.
Goods Issue:- Goods issue needs to be done for the order otherwise the technician cannot perform the maintenance activities that are present in the order.
Goods Receipt:- Goods receipt has to be done for the Internal Refurbishment Order and the settlement will be done for the material.
Material Reservation:- after creating the maintenance order the materials will be reserved in the inventory automatically.
Procurement:- Procuring of non-stock material, service entry sheet through purchase requestion.

Quality Management:- 
CatLog Profile:- Catlog profile will be configured by the quality management team and it will be assigned for the equipment , functional location.
Calibration Order:- In calibration order inspection will be done and thereby the equipment can be used or not will be determined by the quality management team.

SD(Sales And Distribution):- 
The place where the sales and distribution as well as plant maintenance will gets integrated is in customer service module.

EHS(Environment Health & Safety):-
The integration part of PM with EHS comes only at the product safety, Work permit - while performing any maintenance at the dangerous or hazardous material or equipment's.

FREM(Flexible Real Estate Management):- 
Flexible real estate management and plant maintenance both comes under Enterprise Asset Management in SAP S/4 Hana.
Real Estate Object: - Real estate object will be considered as functional location/equipment.
Work order:- Notification and work order management à maintenance requests originating from RE-FX can be turned into PM notifications/ orders but this will be done with the help of CRM.
Service Provider Coordination: - PM order can trigger external services with the help of MM (material management) to work on RE-FX managed asset.

HCM(Human Capital Management):-
Person Responsible:- Here the person can be assigned to the work order , work center, Technical Object, Operations in work order too.

DMS(Document Management System):-
Documents can be uploaded for the technical objects, notifications , work orders etc... for information or to follow the rules to keep the equipment runs smoothly.

The above are some of the modules for which the plant maintenance will integrate with.

Hope its informative and feel free to comment for any improvements or suggestions.

Regards,
Neeraj.
